subsection.title: The Matrix Equation Ax=b.
subsection.p: In this section we introduce a very concise way of writing a system of linear equations: Ax=b. Here A is a matrix and x,b are vectors (generally of different sizes), so first we must explain how to multiply a matrix by a vector.

bluebox.p: When we say A is an m\times n matrix, we mean that A has m rows and n columns. Matrixsize of m\times n\text{ matrix}Size of a matrix

remark.p: In this book, we do not reserve the letters m and n for the numbers of rows and columns of a matrix. If we write A is an n\times m matrix, then n is the number of rows of A and m is the number of columns.

subsection.p: In order for Ax to make sense, the number of entries of x has to be the same as the number of columns of A: we are using the entries of x as the coefficients of the columns of A in a linear combination. The resulting vector has the same number of entries as the number of rows of A, since each column of A has that number of entries.

bluebox.p: If A is an m\times n matrix (m rows, n columns), then Ax makes sense when x has n entries. The product Ax has m entries.

statement.p:
Let A be an m\times n matrix, let u,v be vectors in \R^n, and let c be a scalar. Then:
A(u+v) = Au + Av
A(cu) = cAu
A matrix equation is an equation of the form Ax=b, where A is an m\times n matrix, b is a vector in \R^m, and x is a vector whose coefficients x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n are unknown.

subsection.p:
In this book we will study two complementary questions about a matrix equation Ax=b:
Given a specific choice of b, what are all of the solutions to Ax=b?
What are all of the choices of b so that Ax=b is consistent?
The first question is more like the questions you might be used to from your earlier courses in algebra; you have a lot of practice solving equations like x^2-1=0 for x. The second question is perhaps a new concept for you. The , which is the culmination of this chapter, tells us that the two questions are intimately related.

note.title: Matrix Equations and Vector Equations
note.p:
Let v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n and b be vectors in \R^m. Consider the vector equation x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_nv_n = b. This is equivalent to the matrix equation Ax=b, where A = \mat{ | | {} |; v_1 v_2 \cdots, v_n; | | {} |} \sptxt{and} x = \vec{x_1 x_2 \vdots, x_n}.
Conversely, if A is any m\times n matrix, then Ax=b is equivalent to the vector equation x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_nv_n = b, where v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n are the columns of A, and x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n are the entries of x.

solution.p: Let A be the matrix with columns v_1,v_2,v_3, and let x be the vector with entries 2,3,-4. Then Ax = \mat{ | | |; v_1 v_2 v_3; | | |}\vec{2 3 -4} = 2v_1 + 3v_2 - 4v_3, so the vector equation is equivalent to the matrix equation Ax=\vec{7 2 1}.

note.title: Four Ways of Writing a Linear System

bluebox.p: We will move back and forth freely between the four ways of writing a linear system, over and over again, for the rest of the book.

paragraphs.title: Another Way to Compute Ax
paragraphs.p: The above is a useful way of defining the product of a matrix with a vector when it comes to understanding the relationship between matrix equations and vector equations. Here we give a definition that is better-adapted to computations by hand.

statement.p: A row vector is a matrix with one row. The product of a row vector of length n and a (column) vector of length n is \mat{a_1 a_2 \cdots, a_n} \vec{x_1 x_2 \vdots, x_n} = a_1x_1 + a_2x_2 + \cdots + a_nx_n. This is a scalar.

bluebox.title: Recipe: The row-column rule for matrix-vector multiplication

subsection.title: Spans and Consistency

bluebox.title: Spans and Consistency
bluebox.p: The matrix equation Ax=b has a solution if and only if b is in the span of the columns of A.

subsection.p: This gives an equivalence between an algebraic statement (Ax=b is consistent), and a geometric statement (b is in the span of the columns of A).

statement.p: Let A=\mat[r]{2 1; -1 0; 1 -1}. Does the equation Ax=\vec{0 2 2} have a solution?

figure.caption: The vector w is not contained in \Span\{v_1,v_2\}, so the equation Ax=b is inconsistent. (Try moving the sliders to solve the equation.)

solution.p:
Let us check our geometric answer by solving the matrix equation using row reduction. We put the system into an augmented matrix and row reduce: \amat{2 1 0; -1 0 2; 1 -1 2} \quad\xrightarrow{\text{RREF}}\quad \amat{1 0 0; 0 1 0; 0 0 1}.
The last equation is 0=1, so the system is indeed inconsistent, and the matrix equation \mat[r]{2 1; -1 0; 1 -1}x = \vec{0 2 2} has no solution.

statement.p: Let A=\mat[r]{2 1; -1 0; 1 -1}. Does the equation Ax=\vec{1 -1 2} have a solution?

figure.caption: The vector w is contained in \Span\{v_1,v_2\}, so the equation Ax=b is consistent. (Move the sliders to solve the equation.)

paragraphs.title: When Solutions Always Exist
paragraphs.p: Building on this note, we have the following criterion for when Ax=b is consistent for every choice of b.

statement.p:
Let A be an m\times n (non-augmented) matrix. The following are equivalent:
Ax=b has a solution for all b in \R^m.
The span of the columns of A is all of \R^m.
A has a pivot position in every row.

proof.p: The equivalence of 1 and 2 is established by this as applied to every b in \R^m.

paragraphs.p: Recall that equivalent means that, for any given matrix A, either all of the conditions of the above are true, or they are all false.

bluebox.p: Be careful when reading the statement of the above . The first two conditions look very much like this , but they are logically quite different because of the quantifier for all b.

example.title: Interactive: The critera of the theorem are not satisfied

figure.caption: An example where the criteria of the above are not satisfied. The violet line is the span of the columns v_1,v_2,v_3 of A, which is the same as the set of all b such that Ax=b has a solution. Try dragging b in and out of the column span.

remark.p: We will see in this that the dimension of the span of the columns is equal to the number of pivots of A. That is, the columns of A span a line if A has one pivot, they span a plane if A has two pivots, etc. The whole space \R^m has dimension m, so this generalizes the fact that the columns of A span \R^m when A has m pivots.
